query: What are the effects of exercise on mental health?

claims.statement: Regular physical exercise significantly reduces symptoms of depression, with a moderate-to-large effect size (SMD = -0.62)
evidence: Meta-analysis of 127 studies shows SMD = -0.62 (95% CI: -0.81 to -0.42)
All exercise intensities improved mental health compared to control groups

claims.statement: Moderate-intensity exercise (30-60 minutes, 3-5 times weekly) produces optimal mental health benefits
evidence: Both reviews recommend moderate intensity (50-70% max HR or 40-60% VO2max)
Dose-response analysis shows diminishing returns above 60% VO2max

claims.statement: Exercise benefits require at least 8 weeks of consistent practice to manifest significantly
evidence: Effects most pronounced when exercise maintained for â‰¥8 weeks
Longer durations (>12 weeks) showed more pronounced intensity differences

claims.statement: The optimal exercise intensity for anxiety may differ from depression, with higher intensities potentially more effective for anxiety
evidence: Park et al. found higher intensities (>70% VO2max) showed larger effects for anxiety (SMD = -0.55)
Johnson et al. reported mixed results for panic disorder, requiring further study

claims.statement: High-intensity interval training (HIIT) may be superior to moderate exercise for certain populations
evidence: Some studies favor HIIT citing time efficiency and robust adaptations
Other evidence suggests moderate continuous exercise is more sustainable

claims.statement: Exercise increases BDNF (brain-derived neurotrophic factor) and promotes neurogenesis in the hippocampus
evidence: Neurobiological pathway increases BDNF, promotes neurogenesis
Multi-pathway model supported by both reviews

claims.statement: Long-term maintenance of mental health benefits after exercise cessation requires further investigation
evidence: Uncertainty about effects after stopping exercise

claims.statement: Individual genetic and psychological factors may significantly affect optimal exercise intensity for mental health
evidence: Population subgroup analysis suggests differential responses
